bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George Carroll, May 23, 1941

div1.p: Hench invites Carroll to attend the unveiling of the Walter Reed Yellow Fever group painting.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to George Carroll, May 23, 1941

opener.dateline:
May 23, 1941 Mr. George F. H. Carroll
2814 Rhode Island Ave. N. E.
Washington, D. C.

div1.p:
I am sorry to have bothered you the other day in Washington and I regret
that I happened to phone on a day when it wasn't convenient for you to see me.

I am wondering if there is any possibility that you might be able to be
in Cleveland on June 2. One of the things that I wanted to tell you about was
about a painting which the Wyeth Company has made of the Yellow Fever Commission.
This painting will be unveiled at a private preview in Cleveland. The central
scene is Dr. Lazear inoculating your father, with Walter Reed, Agramonte, Finlay
and others grouped around. It is of course a hypothetical scene, selected by the
artist to show one of the central acts of the drama and to include the other par-
ticipants even though they weren't there at that particular moment. I sincerely
hope that you might be able to go.

I don't believe that the Wyeth people have your address, and if there
is any chance that you might be able to go, I shall be only too glad to give
them your address, with your permission, as I am sure they would be glad to
invite you to be there.

As the time is short, I would appreciate a reply at your earliest
convenience.
div1.closer: Very sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
